ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned essentially all the grammar of the French language and gained a lot of practice with reading, writing, and speaking to French natives.
How to speak, write, and listen to someone talking in French.
Knowledge of the French language, skills of speaking/listening/reading/writing in the French language and insights into French culture.

In this class, you will improve on your skills of reading, speaking, listening, and writing in french in an intensive manner with movies, novels, and music. In doing so, you learn a lot about the culture of francophone countries and their history.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is taught extremely well, and you will definitely come out of it having actually learned French! It is also really fun to be in such a small class that is very tight-knit. That being said, the workload is VERY HIGH - like 2-3 hours of work per night. The professor is really supportive and willing to be flexible, but it was still impossible for me to relax this semester with deadlines every single day and no break besides 5 individual break days. Plus, in order to fit in the syllabus, we had work due after every break day, and class almost always went overtime, which was quite a big stressor for me. While this method certainly succeeds at teaching you French, it is by no means necessary to assign this volume of work to students for them to learn.
The amount of work that the student does will undeniably improve their French.

The strengths of the course are its intensity level, and how much it just throws you into the subject matter, with a whole lot of support (class time, office hours, your fellow classmates, etc.) along the way. There is simply no way that you will not get exponentially better at French if you do even a fraction of all of the work assigned. The weakness, I will say, is one that is is not equal to three credits, when it's the work of three credits (@Yale) and then the Telecom sessions (weekly sessions where you speak to real French people). I think they were organized as best as they could be, from my understanding of the scheduling conflicts and everything, but honestly they were pretty underwhelming. I was hoping to really get to know some French people, but through a confluence of the students, professors and setup, I left feeling quite disappointed. I think it would have been a whole lot better if there had been more consistent meetings, which could have been better planned and facilitated to enable developing real relationships.

One strength of this class is that it is immensely structured. The professor sets up a detailed schedule for assignments and exams and your complete this work so often that it becomes second nature to you within a few weeks. Additionally, the engagement level is very high because the professor tries her best to make the content be applicable to us and interesting. If I were to come up with a weakness for the class, I would say that it's a little more difficult to improve your speaking than the other skills and that more assignments could possibly be geared towards that skill for substantial practice.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was adapted as well as it could be during the pandemic. I wish we could've had class in person, but the professor made use of breakout rooms and other interactive activities to always keep us engaged!
The assignments and the tests were fine.

Honestly, having this course in a Zoom format was probably one of the best ways it could have been taught. Mme. Skorupa is expertly adept at showing all of the various materials we needed, and managing the chatbox, and doing anything and everything possible to make the classroom experience as best as it can be. Obviously I do not know what the in person experience could have looked like, but it is hard to imagine it being better in person. ALSO! Having ten minute breaks were a huge saving grace throughout the course.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you're  serious about learning French, willing to put in the work, and actually have time in your schedule for it!
Yes, but only if you really want to learn French as you will have about 2 hours of homework every night.

Yes, but. This is really not a course you can take if you are at all hesitant about it. Like you will hear from faculty, advisors and this and other reviews, this course is incredibly challenging. It will take up a whole lot of your time, no matter what you do. If you dare take off two days in a row (e.g. Friday and Saturday) you will pay for it on Sunday, or Monday, or Tuesday, or in your final grade. It is an amazing course, and probably the best way to learn French shy of going to a French speaking country, but that does not mean that it will not sometimes feel like an immense slog. But if you are aware of and still willing to commit to it, it can be an amazing way to speed along the process of learning the language/getting the necessary requirements/becoming fluent in French!

If you have an interest in francophone culture and the language, I strongly recommend this course. But the course's workload should not be taken lightly. Of course, it is manageable but you will be doing about 2-3 hours of daily work depending on the unit and 2 hours of class every day. So, there is a very big learning curve at the beginning where you are getting used to that structure and there will be a point where you feel burnt out near the end of the semester. But luckily, the professor is very understanding of this and will work with you to make sure you are successful in the course. And all that work will prove effective by the end of the semester when your linguistic skills improve drastically. You will surprise yourself with how much they've improved.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar, virtual exchange program with students in France
Seminar might not be the best description, because there were more lecture-style classes, and then there were days where it was really just a discussion, but overall it did feel like a seminar.
